Transcript: Cassie: It's official.
Richard: What's that?

Cassie: It's been three whole minutes. Peace 
and quiet. No one begging to stay up past their bedtime and no baby crying.

Richard: And no Camille. I guess she stayed 
for as long as she thought she had to, and then went home back to Iowa.
Cassie: You were right.
Richard: What?
Cassie: You were right.

Richard: I hope so. You could say that a 
little louder if you'd like. It sounds nice.
Cassie: You were right. You were right.
Richard: I was right. I was right.

Alonzo: This is completely out of control. 
There is no possible way I'm doing this. You can not do this to me!
Ben: Haven't you forgotten something?

Marah: Yeah, the underlining economic causes 
for the Civil War. Haven't you forgotten something?
Ben: Like?
Marah: Like how to knock?
Ben: Where are my manners? I'm sorry.
Marah: So, what have I forgotten now?
Ben: That we have a date.

Marah: A date? No, the only date I have is 
with history. I have to finish this term paper.

Ben: We made plans to go skating around the 
town for a Christmas tree.

Marah: I have no idea what you're talking 
about.

Ben: You see, this is why I am the teacher 
and you are the student. Now, as I remember every year Springfield puts a 
Christmas tree up in the middle of Cobbler's pond. And when the pond freezes, 
it's traditional for college students to bundle up and go night skating. 
Afterwards, they cuddle up under blankets, drink hot chocolate or blackberry 
brandy, and generally have a good time. (Laughter) Any questions?
Tony: So, how did we do?

Catalina: Well, we're two cents short. So, 
how about I put in my two cents, so we're even.

Tony: Nah, I think I still owe you. How about 
I buy you a drink?

Catalina: No, actually, I should get back to 
campus. I have this history paper I got to write.
Tony: All right, well, I'll give you a ride.

Catalina: No, you know, why don't you stay 
here? You have work to do.

Tony: I'm fine. I'll take you back to your 
dorm.

Catalina: Why, Tony, so that maybe you can 
run into Marah?

Tony: Wow. Now, what did I do to deserve 
that? I thought I was doing something nice.

Catalina: You were. I'm sorry. It's just 
that... I saw you two together at Towers, and the image has kind of been wearing 
on me.
Tony: You saw us yesterday at Towers?

Catalina: Yeah, yeah, I did. And maybe I 
should have said something early... Earlier, but I thought you would think I was 
spying on you or something.
Tony: And were you?
Catalina: No, Tony, of course not.

Tony: Now, Catalina, I'm a pretty straight 
ahead kind of guy. If there's something you want to ask me, go ahead and ask.
Harley: You lied to me. Not once, not even twice, but over and over again.

Gus: Cooper, it wasn't so much a lie as a 
subtle massaging of the truth, okay?

Harley: Give me a break, massaging? Give me a 
break. You told me you quit the FBI and you were working undercover the whole 
time. That's a lie. That would be called a lie.

Gus: All right! From here on out, no more 
lying...

Harley: Your twisted grudge against Danny 
Santos, your sick quest for justice, I've had it with you. I have had it. You 
know, you can't trust me with the truth, fine. You can be on your way. What, is 
this funny?
Gus: No.
Harley: Is that a smile?

Gus: No, it's just a... Encouragement. It's 
not so much that I lied, that would have been okay. It's that I lied to you, 
right? And... and I’m touched. I just... It gives me hope for the two of us.
Harley: There is no hope for us, none.

Gus: Well, what are you getting so worked up 
over me for?

Harley: Because I am afraid that you are a 
pathological liar, really. I mean you are... You are a law enforcement 
chameleon. You have been so many colors, I don't even know what side you're on 
anymore. What side are you on?
Gus: I'm on my side! Mine. Care to join me?
Harley: No, because I can't trust you.

Gus: Oh, like you've ever had a partner that 
you can trust. What your big doofus brother, Frank or what was his name, Dave? 
Dave, is that his name?
Harley: David.

Gus: These guys treat women cops like they're 
"can-yous" and you know it.
Harley: "Can-yous?"

Gus: Yeah, can you get me a file? Can you get 
me a donut? Can you make my coffee black?

Harley: I get it, I get it. Okay, I get it. 
And you are so off base about that.

Gus: I am the best... The best partner you 
have ever had.
Harley: Yeah, right.

Gus: Yeah, I have. Who was there for you? Who 
has taught you a few things about surveillance in the van back in the day? Who 
was there for you when you gave birth to your baby? Who was there?
Harley: Who wanted you there?

Gus: Yeah, but I was there, right? I was 
there. And what does that tell you?

Harley: You stole the father's cell phone for 
your own self-interest...

Gus: I didn't steal his phone! Are you 
kidding me? I answered the phone by accident. That's all I did. And I was going 
to give him the message, but the guy was acting like a jerk, a jerk! And I 
didn't even... I didn't know that you were in a prison. What, is he still saying 
stuff about that? Is he still complaining about it? I will meet him in the 
parking lot at 3:00 in the afternoon...

Harley: I don't want that. I don't want that. 
I don't want that and I don't want glib, okay? And I don't want, you know, here 
today gone tomorrow. I don't want that. I want somebody who will be here for me 
always. And who will tell me the truth always.
Gus: Okay.

Harley: And who is kind. And you know what? 
You fail in all counts.
Gus: Then you should be with Rick.
Harley: Rick is a great guy...
Gus: Go with it.

Harley: ...Who does not lie, I might add. And 
if Rick would marry me tomorrow and we could raise that child together, I'd do 
it in a second.

Gus: Well, then seal the deal! Go on, beat 
it! Go... go... Go be with the guy! Go on! What's stopping you?
Harley: Nothing anymore.
Cassie: What... What's wrong?
Alonzo: You can't do this to me.
Cassie: Do what to you?

Alonzo: You can't make me sleep in the 
presidential suite.
Richard: Not to your liking?
Alonzo: No, it's not. It's... it's too quiet.
Cassie: Too quiet?

Alonzo: Yeah, it's too quiet. And the list 
goes on from there. The bed is too big. The sheets are way too soft, and the 
maids, they keep coming in and asking if I need anything. I tell you what I 
need.
Cassie: What's that?
Alonzo: I need to get back out to sea.

Cassie: You can't do that. You just had 
surgery.
Alonzo: I don't think you can stop me.

Richard: No, but your surgeon certainly can. 
I don't know what ship is going to commission you without your surgeon's 
approval.

Alonzo: I need to get out of this place. No 
offense. But I've done all I can do here. Will's fine. It's time for me to go. I 
want to hear the waves slapping at the side of my boat, not the changing of the 
guard at the palace gates. And besides, I feel like the third wheel. The two of 
you don't have any privacy with me around.

Cassie: Without you, we wouldn't have a 
healthy son, so.

Richard: The problem is he's starting to like 
it here. He's too comfortable.

Alonzo: Yes, yes, yes. He's right. I'm 
getting soft. It used to be that I could fight a 20-knot wind, just hanging up 
in the webbing of my mizzenmast. Now, I can't even stand up to the two of you.

Cassie: See, that's because we're more like a 
hurricane than a wind.

Alonzo: Fine, fine, spoil me rotten if you 
will. But tomorrow, once the doctor clears me, I’m out of here.
Rick: No, Mel, that was a great idea to test for that particular virus.

Mel: Well, it would have been a good idea if, 
you know, I would have been right.

Rick: That's not true. You know, this is all 
a step up the ladder of figuring out what this thing is and what we're dealing 
with here.

Mel: I think you need to bring in someone 
with more experience. You know, someone who might be able to skip some of the 
rungs of the ladder.
Rick: I've already done that.
Mel: You have?

Rick: Sure. Look, there's a young man's life 
at stake here, you know. There's much more experienced specialists out there 
that can help us out. I have no problem with that, but no matter how many 
specialists we bring in, Mel, this is... This is our case, okay. This is our 
case and I’m glad to be working with you on it, okay?

Mel: Well, I appreciate your faith, Rick, 
but...

Rick: Mel, I'm not going to give you the Rick 
Bauer ego booster tune-up right now. You don't need it and we don't have the 
time. You have a sick man to deal with.
Mel: You're right. I'm sorry.

Rick: This is... This is... This is mind 
boggling, tedious work, and sometimes it's more about endurance and commitment 
than experience. I need somebody who's good, and more important, I need somebody 
who's not going to give up. And there's no question in my mind that you're that 
person. Are you hearing me now?
Mel: Loud and clear.
Rick: Good.

Mel: That sure sounded like the Rick Bauer 
complete ego booster and tune-up.

Rick: No, no, for the complete tune-up, I'm 
going to have to keep you overnight.
Clayton: Hey, hey, hey.
Mel: Hi.
Rick: Hey, Clayton. The cavalry's here.
Clayton: How you doing?
Rick: Good, man, how you doing?

Clayton: Good, good. I got an urgent message, 
though. You all right?

Mel: Oh, I'm fine. I just needed to pick your 
brain.

Clayton: Pick my brain? Ooh, that sounds 
painful, all right. How can I help you?
Mel: It's a work question.

Clayton: Work, at this hour? I thought you 
were the one that said she needs a social life, huh?

Rick: On that note, I’m going to let you guys 
have your father-daughter chat, all right? (Laughter) Good seeing you.
Clayton: So, shoot. How can I help you?
Mel: Zatunica.
Clayton: Zatunica?

Mel: Right. That's the last word Sam Spencer 
said before he went into this weird awake-sleep phase that he's in right now, 
and I have no idea what it is.

Clayton: (Laughs) What, are you kidding me? 
Zatunica?

Mel: Yeah, Zatunica, and I don't know what it 
means.
Clayton: Well, you should.

Rick: What do you mean she's at Infierno? What is she doing there this... No, 
that doesn't matter. Are the kids asleep? Okay, listen, I'm going to swing by 
there and pick her up and we'll be home within an hour, okay? And I got my cell 
phone if you need me for anything. All right, all right, Meta, thanks.

Harley: There was a time when I was afraid to settle down with Rick, but that 
time is over.

Gus: Oh, yeah, what got you ready for him? 
Valium? Tranquilizers? Heavy drinking? Ouzo? That's it?

Harley: No. Just watching you. Watching you 
trash around, doing your thing, destroying your only friendship, destroying your 
career. Hell, your snitches... Hey, don't do that, don't do that...
Gus: Hey, hey...

Harley: ...Don't do that when I am trying to 
talk to you, okay? I hate that. Blowing smoke in my face. It's disgusting. And 
you know, compared to you, Rick's straight-laced life is a sane, inspired 
choice.

Gus: Well, then, you know what? Get ready for 
a long boring year. I picture you both in 40 years on a porch with your little 
foldout chairs, as the big 18- wheelers go by, going, "hey, hey, hey y'all." 
Waste of life. I give it a year. A year.

Harley: Well, thank you for reading my 
future. Do you want to try reading my mind? Give up? I'm thinking it's time for 
you to disappear.

Gus: You know, it doesn't' take a physic to 
see that you and Rick are not a perfect match.
Harley: Who is my perfect match? You? This?
Gus: I am quitting.
Harley: What, smoking?
Gus: No, I'm quitting the Bureau.
Harley: (Laughs)

Gus: You don't believe me? You don't believe 
me? Call my supervisor. She'll tell you...

Harley: Oh, yeah, I’m sure she'll be quick to 
tell me the truth.

Gus: You know something Cooper, sometimes 
you're really just not that fair to me. Or that kind, okay? I have been honest 
with you on the really big things, I have.
Harley: And you name two. You name two.

Gus: I live my life the best way that I know 
how. And I travel around and sometimes you meet a special person. And you take a 
special person with you, the memory of that person. And I think that you're just 
going to be one of those special memories.

Harley: What does that mean? Does that mean 
you're leaving Springfield?
Catalina: Thanks. I should get back.
Tony: Don't go mad.
Catalina: I'm not.

Tony: Listen, I’m sorry I upset you. You're 
the most important thing in my life right now.
Catalina: I'm sorry that I overreacted...

Tony: I said just listen. I don't want to 
make you feel second rate. I wished to all the saints that I had met you before 
I met Marah, but I didn't. And I can't change history.
Catalina: I know you can't.

Tony: But what I can do is make sure that you 
understand that it's just that-- history. Now, I never go back into the past. I 
only go forward into the future. Marah Lewis was the disaster that I call my 
past. And you, you're the dream that I call my future.
Catalina: Yeah?
Tony: Mm-hmm.
Catalina: Now, see now, you can take me home.
Ben: When's the paper due?
Marah: Three days.

Ben: Three days? That's not a deadline, 
that's a lifetime. Now, come on, it is time to punch your time clock.

Marah: I'm not the world's fastest writer and 
this is a really important paper.

Ben: Okay, new plan. You take a two hour 
study break, come back, get eight solid in the sack. Tomorrow morning, you will 
feel like a million bucks. You'll write more history in a half-hour than if you 
stayed up frying your brains out all night long. Now, let's get skating. Where's 
your muff?

Marah: (Laughs) I don't have a muff. And 
I'm not going skating. It's too cold outside. And besides, look at me.
Ben: So, you'll change.

Marah: I can’t. These are my laundry night 
sweats. I'm doing the laundry, I have no clothes to wear. I'm sorry. Look, 
tomorrow, I promise.

Ben: You know what Winston Churchill said, 
don't you?
Marah: No, no, we haven't gotten to him yet.
Ben: Never, never, never give up.
Marah: What are you doing?
Ben: What about this?
Marah: I can't really skate in that.

Ben: Forget the skates, okay? New plan. We 
are going upscale. Given your clothing situation, I feel like we have to 
improvise. Go with the flow.

Marah: Ben, this... This is really the type 
of flow that I just can't afford right now.

Ben: Well, I am buying. There's no point in 
having a trust fund if you're not going to spend it.

Marah: All right, all right, I'll go, I'll 
go. Are you just going to sit there and watch me get dressed?
Ben: I like to watch.
Marah: Not likely.

Ben: You don't think that I can deal with it? 
I can admire a women's beauty without touching her, like I would a work of art.
Marah: Like a work of art?

Ben: Yes. The painting of the woman in the 
clamshell. I think it's a Botticelli.

Marah: All right. I may be the school's 
biggest virgin, but I am definitely no prude. I don't think that you're going to 
be able to handle this work of art.

Ben: Stop. I don't think this is such a good 
idea.

Marah: What happened to all that talk about 
art for art's sake?

Ben: Well, it was just that, okay, talk. 
People might get the wrong idea and you have a reputation to uphold.

Marah: A reputation? What, being the poster 
child for American chastity? I'm tired of that, it's a drag.

Ben: No, it's great. You have standards and 
hopefully, someday, you'll find somebody who can live up to those standards.

Catalina: Whoa. Sorry, didn't mean to 
interrupt.
Richard: Mrs. Mayhew had that framed for us.

Alonzo: Looks like we were having a good 
time.
Cassie: We were.

Alonzo: This is the night that Camille left 
Springfield.

Richard: Yes, that's right. And, by the way, 
have you heard from her? Did she make it back safely?

Alonzo: I don't know. I haven't heard from 
her. We didn't leave on such good terms. Besides, if she was trying to find me, 
she wouldn't look here.
Cassie: Well, I for one am glad to be home.
Alonzo: And far away from Camille.

Cassie: Yes. I think it's best for everyone 
and I hope that Camille will realize that.

Alonzo: I'm sure she will. But just because 
she's out of our lives doesn't mean that she should be forgotten.
Cassie: Absolutely not.

Alonzo: Great. You know what would be a good 
idea? Maybe you could send her some pictures of Will.

Richard: Or we could do better than that if 
you want.
Cassie: We can?

Richard: Well, sure, we could, you know, 
compile an album, you know, apart from our own. You know, photographs, mementos, 
keep track of his first word...

Cassie: I don't want to think that we want to 
keep in contact with Camille.
Alonzo: I think it's a great idea.

Cassie: You guys, what if she changes her 
mind again?

Alonzo: She's not going to. Look, I'm pretty 
sure that she knows that there's no turning back.

Richard: And God forbid, we should need 
another birth parent for any reason, you know, with Alonzo's desire to be at 
sea.

Cassie: Okay, you know, maybe you're right. 
It's just that...
Alonzo: Cassie, Camille's no threat to you.

Cassie: I know that. I'm sorry, okay? I know 
that I'm acting silly, you guys. You're right, you know, we should... We should 
stay in contact with Camille.
Mel: Okay, Dad, I give up. Tell me about Zatunica.
Clayton: Zatunica is in Peru.
Mel: Okay.

Clayton: It's a city that was built in the 
Andes mountains. It's just a pile of ruins now.

Mel: What do Peruvian ruins have to do with 
Sam getting sick here in Springfield?

Clayton: Well, has he traveled out of the 
country recently?

Mel: I don't think so. I'll have to check on 
that, though.

Clayton: Yeah, do that. Check with your boss. 
You said he knows him, right?
Mel: Yeah.
Clayton: How is Rick anyway?

Mel: Well, you know, he's stressed out about 
this. We can't seem to get a diagnosis.

Clayton: Well, no, actually, I was wondering 
how he's doing now that he moved in with Harley and the baby.
Mel: Oh, well, I guess he's fine.

Clayton: Is he in love with her or is he 
motivated by guilt?

Mel: Dad, Rick is not like that. I mean, he's 
just trying to make the best out of a difficult situation. Where are you headed 
with this?
Clayton: Whoa, I'm just curious, that's all.

Mel: You know, Harley is a wonderful woman 
and they share a beautiful baby, and if they're married or living together or in 
love or just doing it for their son, it's not for us to judge or care!

Clayton: Whoa, wait... wait... Wait a minute 
now. Are you trying to convince me or yourself?

Harley: Good riddance. Leave town. See if I care. But it's just so typical. You 
know, it's what men do when the going gets tough, they leave.
Gus: What does that mean?

Harley: It means you've gotten your value 
system from watching too many late night westerns. But believe me, when you ride 
out of town, there's not going to be a kid chasing alongside your house yelling, 
"come back, Gus, come back."

Gus: "Shane." I like that movie. That was 
Gary Cooper, right? So, you don't think I should leave?

Harley: No, I think it's a great idea. 
There's not going to be one person in this whole town who's sad to see you 
leave. How does that make you feel?
Gus: Not a single one?

Harley: There is nothing here to stop you 
from leaving.
Gus: You managed to ruin my last smoke.
Harley: Ask me if I care?

Gus: Do you care? Well, obviously, you don't. 
Well, see you later, kiddo.
Rick: Harley? What are you doing here?
Harley: Rick.
Rick: What's going on?
Harley: I am so happy to see you.

Rick: So, I’m confused here. What's going on 
here? I thought you were heading home.

Harley: I was, but I... I... I just got 
distracted. But I'm focused now. And what I’m most focused on is how lucky I am 
to have such a wonderful man in my life.
Rick: Great, what's his name?
Harley: You, Rick, you.
Rick: (Laughs) Oh.
Harley: What is so funny?

Rick: It's nothing, it's just all of a sudden 
my stock has gone way up tonight. It's just... I don't know, it must be the 
cologne or something.

Harley: I'm trying to tell you something 
important here, and you're making jokes.

Rick: I'm sorry. I didn't know you were 
serious.
Harley: Yeah.
Gus: Does anybody have a match?
Harley: I thought you were gone.
Gus: Well, you remember the movie?
Harley: What movie?
Gus: Remember, "Shane," the guy comes back.
Rick: So, you were here before?

Gus: Well, yeah, if I’m back, it probably 
means I was here before, Rick...
Harley: But he is leaving town for good.
Rick: Well, that's good news.

Harley: I feel like I need to say something 
here. I haven't been honest with you. I've been a coward. I haven't been up 
front about my feelings for him.
Rick: I see.
Harley: Yeah.
Rick: Go ahead.

Harley: You know, I mean, sometimes he... he 
annoys me like he annoys everybody else in town. But there are some times when 
he's made me laugh. And I just... I just haven't been entirely honest with you 
about what I feel for Gus Aitoro.

Mel: What do you mean? I'm not trying to convince myself. I know what Rick’s 
situation is.

Clayton: Well, you just seem a little 
emotional, that's all.
Mel: Well, I do feel emotional about the guy.
Clayton: Yeah, I can see that...

Mel: I mean, we've been thrown together in 
this stressful, demanding work situation, and I’ve seen this totally decent, 
caring guy try to create a home for himself, complete with a child. And I just 
want to see it work out for him. I think he should get everything that he wants 
in life.
Clayton: I understand.

Mel: No, you don't understand. But you know 
what, that's not my problem. I don't have time to explain it to you, because 
I've got some work to do. So, thank you for the geography lesson. I'll call you 
later.
Clayton: All right, bye.
Catalina: Well, that's a very interesting look.
Marah: Yeah, I was just changing.
Catalina: Into what?

Ben: Into this. We are going to Towers. It's 
Christmas break and we're going to celebrate. Hey, why don't we make it a real 
celebration? Come along, we'll make it a double date.
Catalina: Oh, no, Ben, I don't think so.

Tony: I do. I think it's a great idea. Could 
be fun.
Marah: No, I don't think so.

Catalina: Yeah, I don't... I don't think 
that's the best idea.

Ben: Come on, it's settled. We'll wait out 
here while you two get dressed. Excuse me. (Clears throat) So, how's business? 
Good, good, that's good. Is there anything you want to talk about?

Tony: With you? Yeah. We could talk about 
you, and what a slick operator you are. Hey, takes one to know one.
Richard: I've got to make a phone call. Will you excuse me, please?

Alonzo: I am going to put myself back to 
sleep. (Groans)
Cassie: Are you okay?

Alonzo: Yeah. Yep. It's nothing. Just stood 
up too quick. I'll be fine.

Cassie: You don't seem fine. Let me call the 
doctors...

Alonzo: You know what, if you call that 
quack, I don't care what I have to do, I’ll drag myself down to the docks and 
ship out on the next garbage scow.

Cassie: Okay. Guess we'll just see what 
happens.

Alonzo: Right, we'll just see what happens 
and I’ll be fine. And tomorrow, when he gives me the all clear, I’m gone.
Cassie: Is it really that bad?

Alonzo: No. The problem is I like it-- way 
too much.
Ben: And here I thought we were going to have a good time tonight.

Tony: Hey, I'm just the guy who likes to lay 
his cards on the table. I figured you for the same kind of guy.

Ben: I appreciate honesty as much as the next 
guy. Why'd you agree to the double date?
Tony: Because I’m hungry.

Ben: Yeah. Hungry for a certain blonde you're 
still stuck on. Sure, you just want to keep an eye on her.
Tony: It's you I'm keeping an eye on.
Ben: Me? I'm flattered.

Tony: Don't be. Your turn. Why don't you tell 
me what you thought about Marah's essay?

Ben: "The Underlying Economic Causes for the 
Civil War?" I think it's an interesting topic.
Tony: You're a funny guy, aren't you?

Ben: I can be, yes. You're talking about 
"Marah is a virgin" essay. I respect her for it. I think it took a lot of guts 
to write.

Tony: And here I thought you were as honest 
as the next guy.
Catalina: Well, Ben really is a nice guy.
Marah: Yeah, he is.

Catalina: You two certainly have been 
spending a lot of time together.

Marah: I guess so. Why are you so interested 
in my social life all of a sudden?
Catalina: I'm not. Just making conversation.

Marah: You know, you and I could be talking 
about the weather, and somehow it would still end up being about Tony. Look, 
Tony and I had a little talk and we hashed things out, and we came to an 
understanding.
Catalina: I know all about it. Tony told me.

Marah: Good. Then you know that you have 
nothing to worry about. And Tony and I are just friends, and that's all.
Catalina: Yeah.

Alonzo: What's not to like? The life you've shown me here is... Well, it makes 
life sailing the deep blue sea seem kind of empty. And you know what? I wouldn't 
mind having what you and Richard have. Well, minus the palace and the 
presidential jet.
Cassie: I know what you mean.

Alonzo: I want to find a partner. I want to 
spend my life with somebody. Somebody who will be there when times are good, and 
stick with me when things aren't so good. I want that for myself.

Cassie: You deserve that. You do. You're a 
wonderful, caring man, and you deserve the world. Not just the ocean.
Alonzo: Thank you.

Cassie: And if the doctor says it's okay for 
you to leave tomorrow, I will be very sad, and I will miss you dearly, but I 
won't stop you.

Alonzo: I'm going to hold you to that. I feel 
okay now. I'm going to say goodnight.

Cassie: You know, I really do hope that you 
find someone.
Alonzo: So do I. And soon.

Harley: I'm sorry for, you know, blurting that out like that. I just... You 
know, I think I've been... I've been trying to figure out how I feel.
Rick: Oh, please, don't let me stop you.

Harley: Right. So, yeah, he... You know, he 
annoys me and sometimes he makes me laugh, but am I interested in him? No. No. 
No. That was... That was a crazy infatuation is what that was. But now 
everything has worked out the way it's supposed to because he is leaving town. 
And you and I can get on with starting our wonderful life together.

Rick: Harley, it sounds to me like you're not 
sure what you want.

Harley: No, that's not true. That's not true. 
I mean, maybe, you know... Maybe there was a time when I felt something or 
thought I wanted something, but that is gone, okay? You know what this was? It 
was... It was like... You know, like a rebound thing. It was self-destruction, a 
self- destructive urge. But it's gone now. And what I’m looking forward to now 
is getting on with what I want, which is a sane and a healthy, wonderful life 
for my kids with you.

Rick: Harley, are you being honest with me? 
Are you sure? Good. Well, have a nice life, Aitoro. Oh, and be sure to send us a 
postcard from whatever rat hole that you drift into.

Gus: I'm not leaving. Who said I’m leaving? 
Not me.
Ben: Maybe a double date was a bad idea.

Tony: Nah, I think it was a great idea. See, 
I’m going to have fun with Marah and Catalina, and I'm going to be watching you.

Ben: Yeah, well, your time would be better 
spent watching your beautiful girlfriend. Or isn't Catalina enough for you?

Tony: I don't ever want to hear you talk 
about Catalina like that again. She's number one in my life.
Ben: And Marah is?

Tony: She's a good friend. And you're on 
notice. Tony Santos protects his good friends. So, you watch your step. You two 
look beautiful. Let's go.
Richard: Well, that's nice.

Cassie: You... you make me feel loved and 
safe. I'm so lucky.
Richard: We're so lucky.

Cassie: And that is for being right about 
everything.
Richard: What was I right about this time?

Cassie: Camille. You were right. She's no 
threat to me. She's in Iowa somewhere. She's, what, harvesting corn or raising 
barns or whatever it is that they do in Iowa.
Alonzo: I thought I was dreaming.

Camille: It's not a dream. I'm here for you. 
And it's going to be better than it used to be.

Harley: What are you talking about? You told me that you were leaving. Was that 
another one of your little lies?

Gus: No, I... I never said I was leaving. I 
was asking for a reason to stay, and actually, you just gave me a really, really 
big one. You just told me how you felt about me in front of him. And you know 
what? That tells me I should stick around. I should just play my hand, see how 
it goes. So, I'll be seeing you around a lot. Later, Coop.
